item.title: Stop Coding. Start Writing.
item.description:
This hits hard!

LLMs are a “calculator for words” and will only respond to what you put in.

Surely they indeed are the calculator for saphegetti code.

You need to communicate. You went from working directly with code, to needing to communicate your assumptions, and it feels like an increased cost. The thing is, you’re probably not solo and you always should have been communicating when working with others. But writing a design doc was extra work, in the way of completing your immediate task when the code is already working. Now it’s not a side quest, it’s the main quest. You benefit directly from explaining yourself. Less time coding, more time communicating.

item.title: The 12-Month Bug: Why Your Side Project Is Still Just an Idea | Zak El Fassi | Where Code Meets Consciousness - MCP, AI Agents & Information Beings
item.description:
Maybe the fear is for short amount of time, what if we create it? But it turns out to be bad. I am not saying we are not incompetent, I am incompetent but it just breaks when you thought you could make it.

This might be very small percentage of it, but it happens to me every project. Not sure if that is just me, am I really incapable of making that project or is that my motivation lacks after the initial hump.

item.title: Inline Notes
item.description:
This is cool, Maybe I can add this to my own markdown parser?
Maybe not but that is tempting to start writing my own markdown parser and have this little easter egg like syntax for tidbits in the post.

item.title: I used to like software development... but not anymore - Igor Kulman
item.description:
This is a honest and fair take

  • People are too obsessed with productivity, they just don’t do things just for the sake of it, there has to be a evil or some meaning before it exists
    The joy of shear creation is losing in AI slop

item.title: How do arrays work?
item.description: So well explained. It listed the naive array logic and then also gave a better and more possibilities for the reader to be curious and excited about to try.

item.title: You Cannot Outsource Understanding - by Russ Miles
item.description:
So true.
We had assembly to programming language to no-code platforms, and now AI.
They all wanted to outsource the burden of managing or working with developers but eventually they end up in more of those.
Are software engineers really that bad, like people want to remove them?
Why? We solve problems (and end up creating more, but the original problem is indeed solved)

item.title: 15 Go Subtleties You May Not Already KnowGithub icon15 Go Subtleties You May Not Already KnowGithub icon
item.description: A great post linking some gotchas and quirks about the semantics and syntactix of the language

item.title: Karpathy is wrong. Write that post, build that slide deck!
item.description: I agree to that, he might not have said it generally, but after seeing all the jank slop, anyone would prefer the actual work rather than the slop. Because doing it is no LLM can do it, thinking about it, LLMs can make it look very thorugh and promising on the surface, but when you go a little deeper, it breaks apart like hell, you want to tear apart it, and would reject the contennt

item.title: Why bcrypt Can Be Unsafe for Password Hashing ? | enamya | blog
item.description:
Nice to know that bcrypt is not safe for passwords greater than 72 characters, who even would store such a long password.
But that is the thing, subtle decisions, like this is not a password, so we can use bcrypt, and bam you would be wrong

use Argon for this

item.title: Cloudflare outage on November 18, 2025
item.description:
Missing where clause for filtering the default database.
Assumptions about software is a bad thing
Rust won’t protect you from shooting yourself on the foot if you don’t aim properly
